newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bunds higher again as Treasuries support.
newsitem.headline: Bunds higher again as Treasuries support.

text.p: Bund futures continued their yo-yo trading of this week, climbing solidly into positive territory on Thursday and maybe setting the stage for further gains on Friday, traders said.

Bunds took comfort on the day from a stronger Treasury market and the belief that inflation here is a long way off even if it does appear that the Bundesbank may be pondering tightening monetary policy.
The DTB Bund future contract was up 21 basis points at 102.17 at 1410 GMT after having traded in a range between 102.08 and 102.26.

"The market is showing a good bit of stability at higher levels today," said Hans Nordstrom, trader at BMP Wertpapiere und Optionen GmbH. "If we close at these levels, the market could go higher on Friday."
Gains, however, are so far coming largely on the long-end of the yield curve with short-dated maturities hurt by continuing nervousness about a possible increase in German interest rates.
Indeed, the spread between two-and 10-year maturities narrowed by four basis points by late in the day to 178 basis points.

The short-end of the curve could be especially vulnerable to the dollar. One trader said a rebound in the U.S. currency would once again raise speculation of a rate increase which would be felt the most in short dated maturities.

He said that with little threat of inflation, the long end of the curve could even benefit from a tightening of German monetary policy as a sign that the Bundesbank is determined to keep prices under control.
Nordstom said that given a stable Treasury market, he could see the futures contract moving towards 102.50, but expected profit-takers to slow any advance beyond that point.
The benchmark Bund was also higher, trading at 102.37 compared with 102.25 on Wednesday to yield 5.67 percent.
The never-ending tug of war between those who see a prompt start to monetary union and those seeking a delay went to the sceptics on Thursday with a pair of negative EMU comments.

Bavarian Premier Edmund Stoiber continued campaigning for a delay in the launch of EMU, telling a French newspaper "If France or Germany do not respect the criteria to the letter we will find another alternative."

Bundesbank council member Klaus-Dieter Kuehbacher, meanwhile, said the next offical tax revenue estimate for 1997 due in November may show an additional shortfall of 10 billion marks compared with last estimate in May.
The remarks did not have much impact on market prices, however.
Treasuries continued to outperform Bunds on the day, driving the spread to 72 basis points from 78 basis points at the prior close.
